solution_line_template: John has made ${total_made} in {days_worked_initial} days, so this means he makes ${total_made}/{days_worked_initial}=<<{total_made}/{days_worked_initial}={daily_earnings}>>{daily_earnings} dollars a day.
Since John wants to make double his current amount, this means he wants to make {total_made}*{double_multiplier}=<<{total_made}*{double_multiplier}={target_amount}>>{target_amount} dollars
This means John needs to work {target_amount}/{daily_earnings}= <<{target_amount}/{daily_earnings}={total_days_needed}>>{total_days_needed} days in total to make {target_amount}.

As John has already worked {days_worked_initial} days, this means he needs to work {total_days_needed}-{days_worked_initial}=<<{total_days_needed}-{days_worked_initial}={additional_days_needed}>>{additional_days_needed} more days to make his goal.
